segment.source: 4735(S) A security-enabled local group was changed.
segment.target: 4735(S) A security-enabled local group was changed.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4735(S) A security-enabled local group was changed.
segment.target: Describes security event 4735(S) A security-enabled local group was changed.

segment.source: 4735(S): A security-enabled local group was changed.
segment.target: 4735(S): A security-enabled local group was changed.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time a security-enabled (security) local group is changed.
segment.target: This event generates every time a security-enabled (security) local group is changed.

segment.source: This event generates on domain controllers, member servers, and workstations.
segment.target: This event generates on domain controllers, member servers, and workstations.

segment.source: Some changes do not invoke a 4735 event, for example, changes made using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Managed By tab in group account properties.
segment.target: Some changes do not invoke a 4735 event, for example, changes made using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Managed By tab in group account properties.

segment.source: If you change the name of the group (SAM Account Name), you also get “4781: The name of an account was changed” if “Audit User Account Management” subcategory success auditing is enabled.
segment.target: If you change the name of the group (SAM Account Name), you also get “4781: The name of an account was changed” if “Audit User Account Management” subcategory success auditing is enabled.

segment.source: If you change the group type, you get a change event from the new group type auditing subcategory instead of 4735.
segment.target: If you change the group type, you get a change event from the new group type auditing subcategory instead of 4735.

segment.source: If you need to monitor for group type changes, it is better to monitor for “4764: A group’s type was changed.”
segment.target: If you need to monitor for group type changes, it is better to monitor for “4764: A group’s type was changed.”

segment.source: These events are generated for any group type when group type is changed.
segment.target: These events are generated for any group type when group type is changed.

segment.source: “Audit Security Group Management” subcategory success auditing must be enabled.
segment.target: “Audit Security Group Management” subcategory success auditing must be enabled.

segment.source: From 4735 event you can get information about changes of sAMAccountName and sIDHistory attributes or you will see that something changed, but will not be able to see what exactly changed.
segment.target: From 4735 event you can get information about changes of sAMAccountName and sIDHistory attributes or you will see that something changed, but will not be able to see what exactly changed.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “change group” operation.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “change group” operation.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “change group” operation.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “change group” operation.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Group:
segment.target: Group:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of changed group.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of changed group.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the group name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the group name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note Sometimes you can see the GroupSecurity ID field contains an old group name in Event Viewer (as you can see in the event example).
segment.target: Note Sometimes you can see the GroupSecurity ID field contains an old group name in Event Viewer (as you can see in the event example).

segment.source: That happens because Event Viewer caches names for SIDs that it has already resolved for the current session.
segment.target: That happens because Event Viewer caches names for SIDs that it has already resolved for the current session.

segment.source:
Note
Security ID field has the same value as new group name (Changed AttributesSAM Account Name).
segment.target:
Note
Security ID field has the same value as new group name (Changed AttributesSAM Account Name).

segment.source: That is happens because event is generated after name was changed and SID resolves to the new name.
segment.target: That is happens because event is generated after name was changed and SID resolves to the new name.

segment.source: It is always better to use SID instead of group names for queries or filtering of events, because you will know for sure that this the right object you are looking for or want to monitor.
segment.target: It is always better to use SID instead of group names for queries or filtering of events, because you will know for sure that this the right object you are looking for or want to monitor.

segment.source: Group Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the group that was changed.
segment.target: Group Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the group that was changed.

segment.source: For example: ServiceDesk
segment.target: For example: ServiceDesk

segment.source: Group Domain Type = UnicodeString: domain or computer name of the changed group.
segment.target: Group Domain Type = UnicodeString: domain or computer name of the changed group.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For a local group, this field will contain the name of the computer to which this new group belongs, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For a local group, this field will contain the name of the computer to which this new group belongs, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Built-in groups: Builtin
segment.target: Built-in groups: Builtin

segment.source: Changed Attributes:
segment.target: Changed Attributes:

segment.source: Note If attribute was not changed it will have “-“ value.
segment.target: Note If attribute was not changed it will have “-“ value.

segment.source: You might see a 4735 event without any changes inside, that is, where all Changed Attributes apear as “-“.
segment.target: You might see a 4735 event without any changes inside, that is, where all Changed Attributes apear as “-“.

segment.source: This usually happens when a change is made to an attribute that is not listed in the event.
segment.target: This usually happens when a change is made to an attribute that is not listed in the event.

segment.source: In this case there is no way to determine which attribute was changed.
segment.target: In this case there is no way to determine which attribute was changed.

segment.source: For example, this would happen if you change the Description of a group object using the Active Directory Users and Computers administrative console.
segment.target: For example, this would happen if you change the Description of a group object using the Active Directory Users and Computers administrative console.

segment.source: Also, if the discretionary access control list (DACL) is changed, a 4735 event will generate, but all attributes will be “-“.
segment.target: Also, if the discretionary access control list (DACL) is changed, a 4735 event will generate, but all attributes will be “-“.

segment.source: SAM Account Name Type = UnicodeString: This is a new name of changed group used to support clients and servers from previous versions of Windows (pre-Windows 2000 logon name).
segment.target: SAM Account Name Type = UnicodeString: This is a new name of changed group used to support clients and servers from previous versions of Windows (pre-Windows 2000 logon name).

segment.source: If the value of sAMAccountName attribute of group object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of sAMAccountName attribute of group object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For example: ServiceDesk.
segment.target: For example: ServiceDesk.

segment.source: For local groups it is simply a new name of the group, if it was changed.
segment.target: For local groups it is simply a new name of the group, if it was changed.

segment.source: SID History Type = UnicodeString: contains previous SIDs used for the object if the object was moved from another domain.
segment.target: SID History Type = UnicodeString: contains previous SIDs used for the object if the object was moved from another domain.

segment.source: Whenever an object is moved from one domain to another, a new SID is created and becomes the objectSID.
segment.target: Whenever an object is moved from one domain to another, a new SID is created and becomes the objectSID.

segment.source: The previous SID is added to the sIDHistory property.
segment.target: The previous SID is added to the sIDHistory property.

segment.source: If the value of sIDHistory attribute of group object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of sIDHistory attribute of group object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For local groups it is not applicable and always has ““ value.
segment.target: For local groups it is not applicable and always has ““ value.

segment.source: Additional Information:
segment.target: Additional Information:

segment.source: Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of user privileges which were used during the operation, for example, SeBackupPrivilege.
segment.target: Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of user privileges which were used during the operation, for example, SeBackupPrivilege.

segment.source: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “-”.
segment.target: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “-”.

segment.source: See full list of user privileges in “Table 8.
segment.target: See full list of user privileges in “Table 8.

segment.source: User Privileges.”.
segment.target: User Privileges.”.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4735(S): A security-enabled local group was changed.
segment.target: For 4735(S): A security-enabled local group was changed.

segment.source: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
segment.target: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.

segment.source: If you have a list of critical local or domain security groups in the organization, and need to specifically monitor these groups for any change, monitor events with the “GroupGroup Name” values that correspond to the critical local or domain security groups.
segment.target: If you have a list of critical local or domain security groups in the organization, and need to specifically monitor these groups for any change, monitor events with the “GroupGroup Name” values that correspond to the critical local or domain security groups.

segment.source: If you need to monitor each time a member is added to a local or domain security group, to see who added the member and when, monitor this event.
segment.target: If you need to monitor each time a member is added to a local or domain security group, to see who added the member and when, monitor this event.

segment.source: Typically, this event is used as an informational event, to be reviewed if needed.
segment.target: Typically, this event is used as an informational event, to be reviewed if needed.

segment.source: If your organization has naming conventions for account names, monitor “AttributesSAM Account Name” for names that don’t comply with the naming conventions.
segment.target: If your organization has naming conventions for account names, monitor “AttributesSAM Account Name” for names that don’t comply with the naming conventions.
